title: Köttigite
text:
Köttigite is a rare hydrated <a href="zinc">zinc</a> <a href="arsenate">arsenate</a> which was discovered in 1849 and named by <a href="James%20Dwight%20Dana">James Dwight Dana</a> in 1850 in honour of <a href="Otto%20Friedrich%20K%C3%B6ttig">Otto Friedrich Köttig</a> (18241892), a German chemist from <a href="Schneeberg%2C%20Saxony">Schneeberg, Saxony</a>, who made the first chemical analysis of the mineral. It has the formula and it is a <a href="dimorph">dimorph</a> of <a href="metak%C3%B6ttigite">metaköttigite</a>, which means that the two minerals have the same formula, but a different structure: köttigite is <a href="monoclinic%20crystal%20system">monoclinic</a> and metaköttigite is <a href="triclinic%20crystal%20system">triclinic</a>. 
There are several minerals with similar formulae but with other <a href="cations">cations</a> in place of the zinc. <a href="Iron">Iron</a> forms <a href="parasymplesite">parasymplesite</a> ; <a href="cobalt">cobalt</a> forms the distinctively coloured pinkish purple mineral erythrite and <a href="nickel">nickel</a> forms annabergite . Köttigite forms <a href="Solid%20solution%23details">series</a> with all three of these minerals and they are all members of the <a href="vivianite%20group">vivianite group</a>.
The Vivianite Group is a group of <a href="Monoclinic%20crystal%20system">monoclinic</a> <a href="phosphates">phosphates</a> and <a href="arsenate">arsenate</a>s with <a href="divalent">divalent</a> <a href="cations">cations</a>. The group members are <a href="annabergite">annabergite</a>, <a href="arupite">arupite</a>, <a href="babanekite">babanekite</a>, <a href="baricite">baricite</a>, <a href="erythrite">erythrite</a>, <a href="hornesite">hornesite</a>, <a href="kottingite">kottingite</a>, <a href="manganhornesite">manganhornesite</a>, <a href="pakhomovskyite">pakhomovskyite</a>, <a href="parasymplesite">parasymplesite</a> and vivianite. 
Structure.
Köttigite belongs to the <a href="monoclinic%20crystal%20system">monoclinic crystal system</a>, so it has two crystal axes, a and c, inclined to each other at angle β, and a third axis, the b axis, at right angles to both a and c. It belongs to <a href="point%20group">point group</a> 2/m, which means that it has a two-fold axis of <a href="rotational%20symmetry">rotational symmetry</a> parallel to b, and a mirror plane perpendicular to it. The space group is C2/m, which means that the <a href="unit%20cell">unit cell</a> is centred on the C face.
Although zinc is the only transition metal that appears in the formula, köttigite usually contains significant quantities of <a href="cobalt">cobalt</a> and <a href="nickel">nickel</a>, and these three elements are randomly distributed over the cation sites to form complex slabs perpendicular to the b axis. These sheets are held together by <a href="hydrogen%20bonding">hydrogen bonding</a> alone, which is quite weak, hence the perfect <a href="Cleavage%20%28crystal%29">cleavage</a> in this direction.
There are two formula units per <a href="unit%20cell">unit cell</a> (Z = 2) and the cell parameters are a = 10.24 Å, b = 13.405 Å, c = 4.757 Å and β = 105.21°.
Appearance.
Pure <a href="Solid%20solution%23Details">end-member</a> köttigite is colourless, but frequently samples are coloured pink, red, red-orange or brown by elements substituting for the zinc. It is light rose-pink in transmitted light, translucent with a reddish-white to white <a href="Streak%20%28mineralogy%29">streak</a> and a resinous or waxy <a href="Lustre%20%28mineralogy%29">lustre</a>, silky on <a href="Fracture%20%28mineralogy%29">fractures</a>. Crystals are small, <a href="Prism%20%28geometry%29">prismatic</a> parallel to the c axis and flattened perpendicular to the b axis. It also occurs as massive crusts with a crystalline surface and fibrous structure.
Optical properties.
The mineral is <a href="Optic%20axis%20of%20a%20crystal">biaxial (+)</a> with <a href="refractive%20indices">refractive indices</a> nα = 1.622, nβ = 1.638 and nγ = 1.671. The maximum birefringence δ is the difference between the largest and the smallest refractive index, and is equal to 0.049.
Biaxial crystals have two <a href="Optic%20axis%20of%20a%20crystal">optic axes</a>, and the angle between them is known as the optic angle, 2V. For köttigite 2V has a measured value of 74°, and a calculated value of 72°.
Biaxial crystals have three mutually perpendicular principal optical direction, named X, Y and Z. Light travels at different speeds in different directions through the crystal. X is the direction of travel at the highest speed, Z at the lowest, and Y intermediate. The orientation is given by expressing the relationship of X, Y and Z to the crystallographic axes a, b and c. In monoclinic crystals one of the principal optical directions X, Y and Z coincides with the b axis. Since X, Y and Z are mutually perpendicular, it suffices to define just two of them, then the third is determined. For köttigite X=b and Z^c=37°.
<a href="Pleochroism">Pleochroism</a> is visible, with the crystal appearing colourless when viewed along X or Y, and pale red when viewed along Z. Pleochroism should not be present if the mineral is colourless. It is not <a href="fluorescent">fluorescent</a>.
Physical properties.
Köttigite is soft, with <a href="Mohs%20scale%20of%20mineral%20hardness">Mohs hardness</a> only to 3, even softer than <a href="calcite">calcite</a>, which has a hardness of 3. It is also fairly light, with <a href="specific%20gravity">specific gravity</a> 3.33. Because of its sheetlike structure it has perfect <a href="cleavage%20%28crystal%29">cleavage</a> perpendicular to the b axis; it is flexible, and has a fibrous <a href="fracture%20%28mineralogy%29">fracture</a> giving it a silky <a href="lustre%20%28mineralogy%29">lustre</a> on cleavage surfaces. It is soluble in acids.
Occurrence and associations.
It is formed by the alteration of <a href="smaltite">smaltite</a> and <a href="sphalerite">sphalerite</a> . in oxidized zones of <a href="arsenic">arsenic</a>al <a href="ores">ores</a> containing <a href="zinc">zinc</a>. The <a href="Type%20locality%20%28geology%29">type locality</a> is the Daniel Mine (St. Daniel Mine), Neustädtel, <a href="Schneeberg%2C%20Saxony">Schneeberg</a> District, Erzgebirge, Saxony, Germany, where it occurs in oxidized <a href="Vein%20%28geology%29">veins</a> in a <a href="hydrothermal">hydrothermal</a> <a href="sulfide">sulfide</a> <a href="ore%20deposit">ore deposit</a>, associated with <a href="roselite">roselite</a> .
At the <a href="Ojuela%20Mine">Ojuela Mine</a>, <a href="Mapim%C3%AD%20Municipality">Mapimí Municipality</a>, <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>, it occurs in sprays of bladed crystals to 6 mm, which is large for the species, associated with <a href="symplesite">symplesite</a> , <a href="parasymplesite">parasymplesite</a> , <a href="adamite">adamite</a> , <a href="legrandite">legrandite</a> , <a href="metak%C3%B6ttigite">metaköttigite</a> and <a href="gypsum">gypsum</a> .
At the <a href="Hilton%20Mine">Hilton Mine</a>, <a href="Cumbria">Cumbria</a>, England, köttigite has been found in a specimen of <a href="galena">galena</a> and <a href="gersdorffite">gersdorffite</a> (but no <a href="sphalerite">sphalerite</a>), on a surface coated with <a href="annabergite">annabergite</a> and an earthy crust. The individual crystals are colourless, transparent, and very small, the largest being about 1 mm.
At Bou Azzer, <a href="Taznakht">Taznakht</a>, <a href="Morocco">Morocco</a>, köttigite has been identified in a sample of <a href="Vein%20%28geology%29">vein</a> <a href="quartz">quartz</a> rich in <a href="chalcopyrite">chalcopyrite</a> and <a href="sphalerite">sphalerite</a> . The sample has turquoise-blue <a href="Supergene%20%28geology%29">secondary minerals</a> including <a href="devilline">devilline</a> , and also lath-shaped, blue-grey to pinkish grey crystals of köttigite with a habit resembling <a href="erythrite">erythrite</a> , measuring less than 2 mm. The crystals are relatively rich in iron and cobalt, with traces of <a href="copper">copper</a> and <a href="nickel">nickel</a>.
